CARDINAL . DATE LAW provides that everyone shall have the right to a fair and public hearing of his or her case , without undue delay , before a competent impartial and independent court .

CARDINAL . Under LAW § LAW of DATE , everyone is entitled to compensation for damage caused by the unlawful acts of a public authority . Pursuant to LAW of the same LAW , a statute shall not bar access to court to persons seeking redress for any breach of their rights or freedoms .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of the Civil Code provides that the State Treasury shall be liable for damage caused by an official of the ORG acting on the ORG 's behalf .

CARDINAL . Under the former LAW , if damage was caused by the ORG official as a result of his / her giving a decision or doing another official act , ORG was to be liable only if the giving of the said decision amounted to an infringement of laws punishable under the criminal law or under any disciplinary regulations , and if the fault of the perpetrator had been confirmed by a judgment of a criminal court or of a competent disciplinary authority , or was otherwise recognised by a superior authority .

CARDINAL . According to the old case - law of ORG , a plaintiff seeking damages under LAW of LAW must show that the act in question is unlawful and that the ORG agent committed a fault ( ORG judgments : No . I PR CARDINAL/CARDINAL of CARDINAL , unpublished , No . I CR CARDINAL/CARDINAL of DATE , unpublished and No . I CR CARDINAL/CARDINAL of CARDINAL , unpublished ) .

CARDINAL . NORP In its judgment of DATE ORG ruled on the compatibility of these provisions with LAW . It held that LAW was compatible with LAW , if it was construed so as to mean that ORG was liable for damage caused by unlawful acts of public officials in carrying out their duties .

CARDINAL . In the same judgment the ORG held that LAW was incompatible with LAW in that it placed undue restrictions on access to a court in cases in which civil liability of the ORG was sought for acts carried out in the exercise of ORG powers , other than de facto acts , which were covered by the general principle of LAW .
